units.text: Learning Objectives

By the end of this module, Election Judges will be able to understand and mitigate physical, human (insider), and cyber threats. This will be accomplished through review of Election Day responsibilities, with a primary focus on areas of weakness of and/or potential threat to the Electronic Pollbooks (Electronic Pollbooks).
Reference: Keene, K. K., & Livingston, D. E. (2018). Election Judge Manual 2018 (pp. 10.2-10.49) (United States, Board of Elections). Bel Air, MD: Harford County Board of Elections.
Summary:

The security of U.S elections has always been of high concern. However, with awareness of attacks on our elections becoming more frequent, we need to ensure our elections are safe from attack. Because Check-In/Electronic Pollbook Judges are typically the first to interact with voters, you are first line of defense. This module will prepare you to provide the utmost security while in the role of Check-In/Electronic Pollbook Election Judge.

We have identified areas of weak security that can be improved with Election Judge assistance. This module will take you through these areas of weaknesses and provide you with mitigations to improve security.
Together, we can secure the privacy of our elections.
Unpacking the Electronic Pollbook

items: Verify the outer seal number on each case matches the number on the corresponding Opening Equipment Security Report.
Remove the outer seal and place all broken seals in the Broken Seal Envelope.
Handle the Electronic Pollbook with care by removing the pollbook by the elastic band.

Verify the State Asset Tag number on the back of each Electronic Pollbook matches the numbers on the Opening Equipment Security Report for each Electronic Pollbook. Work together in a bi-partisan team with the other Election Judges to ensure accuracy.
Verify the inner seal number on top of each Electronic Pollbook is not broken and number matches the number on the Opening Equipment Security Report for each Electronic Pollbook.
Verify the Power Switch on the top is turned OFF.
Watch/assist other Check-In/Electronic Pollbook Judges when able, to ensure all steps are being done correctly.

units.text: Setting up the Electronic Pollbook (Night Before OR Morning of Elections

items: Ensure the Electronic Pollbook power cord, USB cable from the printer, USB cable from the printer, and USB cable from the hub is connected securely and correctly.
Attempt to cover any open ports on the Electronic Pollbook with painter’s tape.
When connecting the Electronic Pollbook and hub to power via its power cord, be sure to use a power adapter to prevent shortages and electrical damage to the Electronic Pollbook.
Also, be sure to plug the devices in outlet(s) that are out of the reach of voters and heavy foot traffic.
Be sure to keep all cords out of voter path and reach.
Attempt to remove hub from plain sight.

units.text: Election Morning - Using the Electronic Pollbook

items: Check the seal to see if the Electronic Pollbook (Electronic Pollbook) has been tampered with overnight; report any concerns with the seal IMMEDIATELY to the Chief Judge.
Ensure the compact flash (CF) card is located in each Electronic Pollbook.
Be sure to introduce yourself to all other Election Judges. Establish lines of communication in case problems arise.
Turn on each Electronic Pollbook and ensure the date/time are correct.

Follow checklist/training to properly set-up the Electronic Pollbook:
  • Check Synchronization: ALWAYS ensure pollbooks are synchronized. If problems arise, alert a Chief Judge who will seek technical assistance.
  • Throughout the day, periodically check the voted totals at the bottom of the screen against the other Electronic Pollbook(s) in the polling place. All totals should match, but some pollbooks may take a few seconds to synch up with the other pollbooks.
When prompted to sign in, be sure to write out your full name.
Remember: DO NOT check-in voters before 7:00 AM.

units.text: During Election Day - Finding Voters in the Electronic Pollbook

items: When checking in voters, Check-in Judges may not ask for ID but may accept it if offered by a voter.
Regardless, Election Judges must ALWAYS ask the voter to state their name, address, and month and day of birth.
Once a voter is successfully identified, print out their voter registration card (VAC). Have the voter verify the information is correct by signing the appropriate line.
If their information is not correct, follow-up with the appropriate actions. When in doubt, ask for help from fellow Check-in Judges and/or the Chief Judge.

NEVER leave your pollbook unattended. When helping a voter for an extended period of time, SIGN OUT of your pollbook.
  • This will help prevent any unauthorized users from accessing and/or tampering with the pollbook.
  • Review “Resetting the Judges Name” in the “Electronic Pollbook” section of the Election Judge Manual.

If you have ANY issues with a voter, especially in “Special Situations,” DO NOT hesitate to ask the Chief Judge for assistance.
  • Refrain from asking occupied Check-In/Electronic Pollbook Judges for assistance.

units.text: Closing the Polls

items: Ensure the Electronic Pollbook and all related materials are returned to their cases.
See that the Chief Judge receives all Electronic Pollbook material before successfully closing the location.

units.text: Equipment Management Assessment

units.prompt: You are currently checking-in a voter. You have asked the three required questions and used their name to look up the voter in the Electronic Pollbook. While asking the three required questions, the voter gives you an address that does not match what is on the Electronic Pollbook. What are you NOT to do?

choices.text: Continue to issue regular ballot.
Ask voter if they have moved within the last three weeks.
Ask a fellow Election Judge or Chief Judge for assistance.

units.prompt: You notice your neighboring Electronic Pollbook Election Judge sign into the Electronic Pollbook using their initials. What should you do?

choices.text: Leave them be, at least they are signing in.
Politely let them know it is required they sign in with their full name. Offer them instructions on how to sign in again.
Tell the Chief Judge.
Yell at them.

units.prompt: It is about 9:00AM and you decide to check the Electronic Pollbook synchronization. You notice that your Electronic Pollbook says DEM 34 and your neighbors Electronic Pollbook says DEM 32. What should you do?

choices.text: Notify the Chief Judge immediately.
Wait about 30 seconds to see if the Electronic Pollbooks count matches up. If it does not match up within a minute, notify the Chief Judge.
Disconnect the Electronic Pollbooks from the hub for 10 seconds, then reconnect.
Disconnect the hub from its power source, wait 10 seconds, then reconnect to power.

units.prompt: You have successfully followed all steps to set-up the Electronic Pollbook, and it is not prompting you to record a judge's name. How do you identify yourself?

choices.text: Write your initials.
Write out your last name.
Write your date of birth.
Write out your first and last name.

units.prompt: Which form of ID is acceptable?

choices.text: Out-of-state driver’s license.
An expired photo ID card.
Any non-photo ID that is more than 3 months old.
A membership card (Sam’s Club, gym, etc.).
A Voter Notification Card.
A Social Security Card.
Any non-photo ID with an address that does NOT match the Electronic Pollbook or the new address on the Voter Update Form.
None of the above.

units.prompt: When unpacking an Electronic Pollbook, how do you verify that it belongs at your polling location?

choices.text: Ensure the outer and inner seal number of the Electronic Pollbook matches the number on the Opening Equipment Security Report for each respective Electronic Pollbook.
Ask the Chief Judge to check each Electronic Pollbook.
Verify the outer seals on the Electronic Pollbooks have not been broken.
If they come out of the black carrying case, then those are the correct Electronic Pollbooks for that polling location.

units.text: In this section, we will work to reduce the chances of a cyber threat within our polling locations.
As an Electronic Pollbook/Check-In Judge, you can reduce the chance of unauthorized equipment/data tampering through remote access using electronic devices in the polling location.
You can reduce cyber threats by:

items:
NOT using your cell phone or any other electronic device while at the polling location. Cell phone/technology usage is PROHIBITED for voters and Election Judges in the polling place.
  • Use of any technology poses a silent but dangerous cyber threat to our elections and must be removed IMMEDIATELY.
Being aware of suspicious and/or adverse behavior and actions.
Watching over other Election Judges, observers, voters, and election material.
Providing assistance ONLY when you are available.

Notifying the Chief Judge of ANY AND ALL suspicious or adverse behavior or actions from fellow Election Judges, observers, voters, etc.
  • Individuals posing as Election Judges may attempt to tamper with election equipment/processes.

units.text: Cyber Threat Assessment

units.prompt: You notice a fellow Electronic Pollbook Judge texting under the table with their cell phone. What should you do?

choices.text: Politely ask them to put their phone away.
Remind them that voter nor election judges are permitted to use their cell phones in the polling location.
Politely ask the election judge to step outside of the polling place to use their cell phone.
Any of the above.

units.prompt: While scanning the polling location, you notice the Scanning Unit Election Judge sleeping in their chair. What should you do?

choices.text: Leave your station to wake the sleeping Election Judge.
Notify the Chief Judge
Throw a piece of paper at the sleeping Election Judge.
Scream at the sleeping Election Judge.

units.prompt: As an Electronic Pollbook Election Judge, how can you determine if your Electronic Pollbook has been tampered with during voting hours?

choices.text: The seal on the Electronic Pollbook itself shows signs of meddling.
You did not sign out of your Electronic Pollbook before leaving your station.
Your Electronic Pollbook does not successfully sync with other Electronic Pollbooks in a reasonable amount of time.
All of the above.

units.text: This section will aid you in identifying and mitigating the impact of insider threats at your polling location.

The most obvious insider threats involve Election Judges compromising the election process by posing as an Election Judge and deliberately tampering with election devices, thus corrupting the process; observers distracting election officials; and individuals posing as observers actually being malicious actors.

You can reduce and prevent insider threat by being vigilant and aware during polling place set-up, while preparing the Electronic Pollbook on election morning, throughout the day when registering voters, and while assisting in closing the polling location.
If any situation arises when an observer must become involved, never leave your equipment unattended and immediately contact the Chief Judge.
Insider Threat Assessment

units.prompt: You are checking in a voter when an observer comes to you and questions the voter's right to vote, giving their probable cause. What are you to do?

choices.text: Get up and retrieve the Chief Judge.
Stop what you are doing and call upon the Chief Judge.
Explain why this person can vote at the designated precinct.
As the Election Judge beside you for help to prove the voeter can vote at the designated precinct.

units.prompt: You witness a person wearing a grey jacket, repeatedly re-enter then leave the entrance of the polling location. What should you do about your suspicions?

choices.text: Nothing. This is a free country and the person can do as they please.
Talk about it with other Check-in Judges.
Promptly notify the Chief Judge of your suspicions.
Leave your station to ask the suspicious person to stop their distracting activities.

units.prompt: How do you protect the information stored in the Electronic Pollbook when you leave your station during voting hours?

choices.text: Flip the Electronic Pollbook on its screen so no one can press buttons or touch the screen.
Have the Chief Judge or another Election Judge watch your Electronic Pollbook while you step out.
Unplug or disconnect the Electronic Pollbook from its power source until you return to your station.
Sign out of your assigned Electronic Pollbook each time you leave your station.

units.text: In this final section, you will learn how to reduce/prevent physical threats to our elections at your designated polling location.
Some physical threats that our elections are susceptible to include memory stick(s) being compromised, individuals stealing passwords, and resetting polling machine settings prior to the election.
Election Morning

items:
Ensure the Electronic Pollbooks show NO evidence of tampering.
  • Check tamper tape.
  • Ensure each Electronic Pollbook contains a Compact Flash (CF).

units.text: During Election Day

items:
Be aware and watch over other persons in the polling location. Provide assistance only when available.
  • NEVER to leave your pollbook unattended. When helping a voter for an extended period of time, SIGN OUT of your pollbook.
Watch/assist other Check-In/Electronic Pollbook Election Judges when able to ensure all steps are being done correctly.

Notify the Chief Judge of ANY AND ALL suspicious or adverse behavior or actions from fellow Election Judges, observers, voters, etc. Individuals posing as Election Judges may attempt to tamper with election equipment/processes.

units.text: Closing the Polls

items: When closing the polling location, ensure EACH Electronic Pollbook Compact Flash card is placed in its proper security envelope and given directly to the Chief Judge.

units.text: Physical Threat Assessment

units.prompt: The polling place has been closed. You and the fellow Electronic Pollbook Judges are shutting down the Electronic Pollbooks. If needed, what can you do to further assist the Chief Judge?

choices.text: Collect/record each compact flash card, place in its designated security envelope, and hand to the Chief Judge.
Stay out of the way.
Network with fellow Election Judges.
Turn on your phone and catch up on missed notifications.

units.prompt: It has been three hours since the polls opened and you need to use the restroom. What should you do?

choices.text: Look to see if there are any incoming voters; if not, run to the restroom.
Tell your fellow Check-in Judges you will be using the restroom and then leave.
Notify your fellow Check-in Judges and Chief Judge. When voter traffic slows down, sign out of your Electronic Pollbook and quickly use the restroom.

units.prompt: What item must be removed from each Electronic Pollbook when closing the loop?

choices.text: The Electronic Pollbook Compact Flash Card.
The stylus used to touch the Electronic Pollbook screen.
Nothing, all components of the Electronic Pollbook are returned to the case they came out of.
Yourself! It's time to go.
